Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Before we start the debate here are the rules.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: The candidates have one minute to respond to our questions and 30 seconds to respond to our follow-up.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Any candidate who is attacked by another candidate gets 30 seconds for rebuttal.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Here's how we'll keep time, after a question is asked the green light goes on.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: When there are 15 seconds left the candidate gets a yellow warning light.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: And when time's up the light turns red.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: That means stop talking.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: [laughter] Those are the rules.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: So let's get started.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: You will each have one minute for an opening statement to share your thoughts about the attacks in your Paris and lay out your visions for America.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: First, Senator Sanders.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: Well, John, let me concur with you and with all Americans who are shocked and disgusted by what we saw in Paris yesterday.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: Together, leading the world, this country will rid our planet of this barbarous organization called ISIS.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: I'm running for president, because as I go around this nation, I talk to a lot of people.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: And what I hear is people's concern that the economy we have is a rigged economy.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: People are working longer hours for lower wages, and almost all of the new income and wealth goes to the top one percent.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: And then on top of that, we've got a corrupt campaign finance system in which millionaires and billionaires are pouring huge sums of money into super PACS heavily influencing the political process.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: What my campaign is about is a political revolution -- millions of people standing up and saying, enough is enough.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: Our government belongs to all of us, and not just the hand full of billionaires.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: All right, Senator Sanders.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Secretary Clinton.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Well, our prayers are with the people of France tonight, but that is not enough.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: We need to have a resolve that will bring the world together to root out the kind of radical jihadist ideology that motivates organizations like ISIS, a barbaric, ruthless, violent jihadist terrorist group.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: This election is not only about electing a president.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: It's also about choosing our next commander-in-chief.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: And I will be laying out in detail, what I think we need to do with our friends and allies in Europe and elsewhere to do a better job of coordinating efforts against the scourge of terrorism.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Our country deserves no less, because all of the other issues we want to deal with depend upon us being secure and strong.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Governor O'Malley.

Speaker: O
Sents: My heart, like all of us in this room, John, and all the people across our country, my hearts go out to the people of France in this moment of loss.

Speaker: O
Sents: Parents, and sons, and daughters and family members, and as our hearts go out to them and as our prayers go out to them, we must remember this, that this isn't the new face of conflict and warfare, not in the 20th century but the new face of conflict and warfare in the 21st century.

Speaker: O
Sents: And there is no nation on the planet better able to adapt to this change than our nation.

Speaker: O
Sents: We must able to work collaboratively with others.

Speaker: O
Sents: We must anticipate these threats before they happen.

Speaker: O
Sents: This is the new sort of challenge, the new sort of threat that does, in fact, require new thinking, fresh approaches and new leadership.

Speaker: O
Sents: As a former mayor and a former governor, there was never a single day, John, when I went to bed or woke up without realizing that this could happen in our own country.

Speaker: O
Sents: We have a lot of work to do, to better prepare our nation and to better lead this world into this new century.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: All right, thank you, Governor.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Thank all of you.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: The terror attacks last night underscore biggest challenge facing the next president of the United States.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: At a time of crisis, the country and the world look to the president for leadership and for answers.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: So, Secretary Clinton, I'd like to start with you.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Hours before the attacks, President Obama said, "I don't think ISIS is gaining strength."

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Seventy-two percent of Americans think the fight against ISIS is going badly.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Won't the legacy of this administration, which is-- which you were a part of, won't that legacy be that it underestimated the threat from ISIS?

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Well, John, I think that we have to look at ISIS as the leading threat of an international terror network.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: It cannot be contained, it must be defeated.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: There is no question in my mind that if we summon our resources, both our leadership resources and all of the tools at our disposal, not just military force, which should be used as a last resort, but our diplomacy, our development aid, law enforcement, sharing of intelligence in a much more open and cooperative way -- that we can bring people together.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: But it cannot be an American fight.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: And I think what the president has consistently said-- which I agree with-- is that we will support those who take the fight to ISIS.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: That is why we have troops in Iraq that are helping to train and build back up the Iraqi military, why we have special operators in Syria working with the Kurds and Arabs, so that we can be supportive.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: But this cannot be an American fight, although American leadership is essential.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: But as -- Secretary Clinton, the question was about, was ISIS underestimated?

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: And I'll just add, the president referred to ISIS as the JVU (sic), in a speech at the Council of Foreign Relations in June of 2014 said, "I could not have predicted the extent to which ISIS could be effective in seizing cities in Iraq."

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: So you've got prescriptions for the future, but how do we even those prescript prescriptions are any good if you missed it in the past?

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Well, John, look, I think that what happened when we abided by the agreement that George W. Bush made with the Iraqis to leave by 2011, is that an Iraqi army was left that had been trained and that was prepared to defend Iraq.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Unfortunately, Nouri al-Maliki, the prime minister, set about decimating it.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: And then, with the revolution against Assad -- and I did early on say we needed to try to find a way to train and equip moderates very early so that we would have a better idea of how to deal with Assad because I thought there would be extremist groups filling the vacuum.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: So, yes, this has developed.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: I think that there are many other reasons why it has in addition to what happened in the region, but I don't think that the United States has the bulk of the responsibility.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: I really put that on Assad and on the Iraqis and on the region itself.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Okay, Governor O'Malley, would you critique the administration's response to ISIS.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: If the United States doesn't lead, who leads?

Speaker: O
Sents: John, I would disagree with Secretary Clinton respectfully on this score.

Speaker: O
Sents: This actually is America's fight.

Speaker: O
Sents: It cannot solely be America's fight.

Speaker: O
Sents: America is best when we work in collaboration with our allies.

Speaker: O
Sents: America is best when we are actually standing up to evil in this world.

Speaker: O
Sents: And ISIS, make no mistake about it, is an evil in this world.

Speaker: O
Sents: ISIS has brought down a Russian airliner.

Speaker: O
Sents: ISIS has now attacked a western democracy in -- in France.

Speaker: O
Sents: And we do have a role in this.

Speaker: O
Sents: Not solely ours, but we must work collaboratively with other nations.

Speaker: O
Sents: The great failing of these last 10 or 15 years, John, has been our failing of human intelligence on the ground.

Speaker: O
Sents: Our role in the world is not to roam the globe looking for new dictators to topple.

Speaker: O
Sents: Our role in the world is to make ourselves a beacon of hope.

Speaker: O
Sents: Make ourselves stronger at home, but also our role in the world, yes, is also to confront evil when it rises.

Speaker: O
Sents: We took out the safe haven in Afghanistan, but now there is, undoubtedly, a larger safe haven and we must rise to this occasion in collaboration and with alliances to confront it, and invest in the future much better human intelligence so we know what the next steps are.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Senator Sanders, you said you want to rid the planet of ISIS.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: In the previous debate you said the greatest threat to national security was climate change.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Do you still believe that?

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: Absolutely.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: In fact, climate change is directly related to the growth of terrorism.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: And if we do not get our act together and listen to what the scientists say, you're going to see countries all over the world -- this is what the CIA says -- they're going to be struggling over limited amounts of water, limited amounts of land to grow their crops ask you're going to see all kinds of international conflict.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: But, of course, international terrorism is a major issue that we have got to address today.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: And I agree with much of what the Secretary and the Governor have said.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: But let me have one area of disagreement with the Secretary.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: I think she said something like the bulk of the responsibility is not ours.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: Well, in fact, I would argue that the disastrous invasion of Iraq, something that I strongly opposed, has unraveled the region completely and led to the rise of al-Qaeda and to ISIS.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: Now, in fact, what we have got to do -- and I think there is widespread agreement here -- is the United States cannot do it alone.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: What we need to do is lead an international coalition which includes very significantly the Muslim nations in that region who are going to have to fight and defend their way of life.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Quickly, just let me ask you a follow-up on that, Senator Sanders.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: When you say the disastrous vote on Iraq, let's just be clear about what you're saying.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: You're saying Secretary Clinton, who was then Senator Clinton, voted for the Iraq war.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: And are you making a direct link between her vote for that or and what's happening now for ISIS.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Just so everybody...

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: I don't think any -- I don't think any sensible person would disagree that the invasion of Iraq led to the massive level of instability we are seeing right now.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: I think that was one of the worst foreign policy blunders in the more than history of the United States.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Alright.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Let's let Secretary Clinton respond to that.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Thank you, John.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Well, thank you, John.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: I think it's important we put this in historic context.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: The United States has, unfortunately, been victimized by terrorism going back decades.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: In the 1980s, it was in Beirut, Lebanon, under President Reagan's administration, and 258 Americans, marines, embassy personnel, and others were murdered.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: We also had attacks on two of our embassies in Tanzania, Kenya, when my husband was president.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Again, Americans murdered.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: And then, of course, 9/11 happened, which happened before there was an invasion of Iraq.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: I have said the invasion of Iraq was a mistake.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: But I think if we're ever going to really tackle the problems posed by jihadi extreme terrorism, we need to understand it and realize that it has antecedents to what happened in Iraq and we have to continue to be vigilant about it.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Senator Sanders let me just follow this line of thinking.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: You criticized then, Senator Clinton's vote.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Do you have anything to criticize in the way she performed as Secretary of State?

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: I think we have a disagreement, and the disagreement is that not only did I vote against the war in Iraq.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: If you look at history, John, you will find that regime change -- whether it was in the early '50s in Iran, whether it was toppling Salvador Allende in Chile, whether it is overthrowing the government of Guatemala way back when -- these invasions, these toppling of governments, regime changes have unintended consequences.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: I would say that on this issue, I'm a little bit more conservative than the Secretary...

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Alright.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: ... And that I am not a great fan of regime change.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Senator let me...

Speaker: O
Sents: John, may I -- may I interject here?

Speaker: O
Sents: Secretary Clinton also said we -- it was not just the invasion of Iraq which Secretary Clinton voted for and has since said was a big mistake -- and, indeed, it was.

Speaker: O
Sents: But it was also the cascading effects that followed that.

Speaker: O
Sents: It was also the disbanding of many elements of the Iraqi army that are now showing up as part of ISIS.

Speaker: O
Sents: It was country after country without making the investment in human intelligence to understand who the new leaders were and the new forces were that are coming up.

Speaker: O
Sents: We need to be much more far thinking in this new 21st century era of -- of nation state failures and conflict.

Speaker: O
Sents: It's not just about getting rid of a single dictator.

Speaker: O
Sents: It is about understanding the secondary and third consequences that fall next.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: All right, Secretary Clinton.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Well, of course, each of these cases needs to be looked at individually and analyzed.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Part of the problem that we have currently in the Middle East is that Assad has hung on to power with the very strong support of Russia and Iran and with the proxy of Hezbollah being there basically fighting his battles.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: So I don't think you can paint with a broad brush.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: This is an incredibly complicated region of the world.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: It's become more complicated.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: And many of the fights that are going on are not ones that the United States has either started or have a role in.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: The Shi'a-Sunni split.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: The dictatorships have suppressed people's aspirations.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: The increasing globalization without any real safety valve for people to have a better life.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: We saw that in Egypt.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: We saw a dictator overthrown.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: We saw a Muslim brotherhood president installed, and then we saw him ousted and the army back.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: So, I think we've got to understand the complexity of the world that we are facing and no place is more so than in the Middle East.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: I understand.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Quickly, Senator.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: The Secretary's obviously right.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: It is enormously complicated.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: But here's something that I believe we have to do as we put together an international coalition, and that is we have to understand that the Muslim nations in the region -- Saudi Arabia, Iran, Turkey, Jordan -- all of these nations, they're going to have to get their hands dirty, their boots on the ground.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: They are going to have to take on ISIS.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: This is a war for the soul of Islam.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: And those countries who are opposed to Islam, they are going to have to get deeply involved in a way that is not the case today.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: We should be supportive of that effort.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: So should the UK, so should France.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: But those Muslim countries are going to have to lead the effort.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: They are not doing it now.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Secretary Clinton.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Well, I think -- I think that is very unfair to a few you mentioned, most particularly Jordan, which has put a lot on the line for the United States, has also taken in hundreds of thousands of refugees from Syria, and has been, therefore, subjected to threats and attacks by extremists themselves.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: I do agree that in particular, Turkey and the Gulf nations have got to make up their minds.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Are they going to stand with us against this kind of jihadi radicalism or not?

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: And there are many ways of doing it.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: They can provide forces.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: They can provide resources.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: But they need to be absolutely clear about where they stand.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Let me ask you, Secretary Clinton, a question about leadership.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: We're talking about what role does America take?

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Let me ask you about Libya.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: So Libya is a country in which ISIS has taken hold in part because of the chaos after Muammar Gaddafi.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: That was an operation you championed.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: President Obama says this is the lesson he took from that operation.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: In an interview he said, the lesson was, do we have an answer for the day after?

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Wasn't that suppose to be one of the lessons that we learned after the Iraq war?

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: And how did you get it wrong with Libya if the key lesson of the Iraq war is have a plan for after?

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Well, we did have a plan, and I think it's fair to say that of all of the Arab leaders, Gaddafi probably had more blood on his hands of Americans than anybody else.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: And when he moved on his own people, threatening a massacre, genocide, the Europeans and the Arabs, our allies and partners, did ask for American help and we provided it.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: And we didn't put a single boot on the ground, and Gaddafi was deposed.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: The Libyans turned out for one of the most successful, fairest elections that any Arab country has had.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: They elected moderate leaders.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Now, there has been a lot of turmoil and trouble as they have tried to deal with these radical elements which you find in this arc of instability, from north Africa to Afghanistan.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: And it is imperative that we do more not only to help our friends and partners protect themselves and protect our own homeland, but also to work to try to deal with this arc of instability, which does have a lot of impact on what happens in a country like Libya.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Governor O' Malley I want to ask you a question and you can add whatever you'd like to.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: But let me ask you, is the world too dangerous a place for a governor who has no foreign policy experience?

Speaker: O
Sents: John, the world is a very dangerous place, but the world is not too dangerous of a place for the United States of America, provided we act according to our principles, provided we act intelligently.

Speaker: O
Sents: I mean, let's talk about this arc of instability that Secretary Clinton talked about.

Speaker: O
Sents: Libya is now a mess.

Speaker: O
Sents: Syria is a mess.

Speaker: O
Sents: Iraq is a mess.

Speaker: O
Sents: Afghanistan is a mess.

Speaker: O
Sents: As Americans, we have shown ourselves to have the greatest military on the face of the planet, but we are not so very good at anticipating threats and appreciating just how difficult it is to build up stable democracies, to make the investments and sustainable development that we must as a nation if we are to attack the root causes of these sorts of instability.

Speaker: O
Sents: And I wanted to add one other thing, John, and I think it's important for all of us on this stage.

Speaker: O
Sents: I was in Burlington, Iowa.

Speaker: O
Sents: And a mom of a service member of ours who served two duties in Iraq said, Governor O' Malley, please, when you're with your other candidates and colleagues on stage, please don't use the term 'boots on the ground'.

Speaker: O
Sents: Let's don't use the term 'boots on the ground'.

Speaker: O
Sents: My son is not a pair of boots on the ground.

Speaker: O
Sents: These are American soldiers and we fail them when we fail to take into account what happens the day after a dictator falls and when we fail to act with a whole of government approach with sustainable development, diplomacy, and our economic power in alignment with our principles.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Well, I think it's perfectly fair to say that we invested quite a bit in development aid.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Some of the bravest people that I had the privilege of working with as secretary of state were our development professionals who went sometimes alone, sometimes with our military, into very dangerous places in Iraq, in Afghanistan, elsewhere.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: So, there does need to be a whole of government approach, but just because we're involved and we have a strategy doesn't mean we're going to be able to dictate the outcome.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: These are often very long- term kinds of investments that have to be made.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: [crosstalk]

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: When you talk about the long-term consequences of war, let's talk about the men and women who came home from war.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: The 500,000 who came home with PTSD, and traumatic brain injury.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: And I would hope in the midst of all of this discussion, this country makes certain that we do not turn our backs on the men and women who put their lives on the line to defend us, and that we stand with them as they have stood with us.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Secretary Clinton, you mentioned radical jihadists.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Marco Rubio, also running for president, said that this attack showed and the attack in Paris showed that we are at war with radical Islam.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Do you agree with that characterization, radical Islam?

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: I don't think we're at war with Islam.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: I don't think we're at war with all Muslims.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: I think we're at war with jihadists who have --

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Just to interrupt.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: He didn't say all Muslims.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: He just said radical Islam.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Is that a phrase you don't...

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: I think THAT you can talk about Islamists who clearly are also jihadists, but I think it's not particularly helpful to make the case that Senator Sanders was just making that I agree with, that we've got to reach out to Muslim countries.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: We've got to have them be part of our coalition.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: If they hear people running for president who basically shortcut it to say we are somehow against Islam, that was one of the real contributions, despite all the other problems, that George W. Bush made after 9/11 when he basically said after going to a Mosque in Washington, we are not at war with Islam or Muslims.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: We are at war with violent extremism.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: We are at war with people who use their religion for purposes of power and oppression.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: And, yes, we are at war with those people.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: But I don't want us to be painting with too broad a brush.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: The reason I ask is you gave a speech at Georgetown University in which you said, that it was important to show, quote, "respect, even for one's enemies.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Trying to understand and in so far as psychologically possible, empathize with their perspective and point of view."

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Can you explain what that means in the context of this kind of barbarism?

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: I think with this kind of barbarism and nihilism, it's very hard to understand, other than the lust for power, the rejection of modernity, the total disregard for human rights, freedom, or any other value that we know and respect.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Historically, it is important to try to understand your adversary in order to figure out how they are thinking, what they will be doing, how they will react.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: I plead that it's very difficult when you deal with ISIS and organizations like that whose behavior is so barbaric and so vicious that it doesn't seem to have any purpose other than lust for killing and power and that's very difficult to put ourselves in the other shoe.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: [crosstalk]

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Just quickly, do either of you, radical Islam, do either of you use that phrase?

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: I don't think the term is what's important.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: What is important to understand is we have organizations, whether it is ISIS or Al Qaida, who do believe we should go back several thousand years.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: We should make women third-class citizens, that we should allow children to be sexually assaulted, that they are a danger to modern society.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: And that this world, with American leadership, can and must come together to destroy them.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: We can do that.

Speaker: SANDERS
Sents: And it requires an entire world to come together, including in a very active way, the Muslim nations.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Governor O' Malley, you have been making the case when you talk about lack of forward vision, you're essentially saying that Secretary Clinton lacks that vision and this critique matches up with this discussion of language.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: The critique is that the softness of language betrays a softness of approach.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: So if this language -- if you don't call it by what it is, how can your approach be effective to the cause?

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: that's the critique.

Speaker: O
Sents: I believe calling it what it is, is to say radical jihadis.

Speaker: O
Sents: That's calling it what it is.

Speaker: O
Sents: But John, let's not fall into the trap of thinking that all of our Muslim American neighbors in this country are somehow our enemies here.

Speaker: O
Sents: They are our first line of defense.

Speaker: O
Sents: And we are going to be able to defeat ISIS on the ground there, as well as in this world, because of the Muslim Americans in our country and throughout the world who understand that this brutal and barbaric group is perverting the name of a great world religion.

Speaker: O
Sents: And now, like never before, we need our Muslim American neighbors to stand up and to -- and to be a part of this.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: Secretary Clinton, the French president has called this attack an act of war.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Yes.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: A couple of days ago you were asked if you would declare war on ISIS and you said no.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: What would you say now?

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: Well, we have an authorization to use military force against terrorists.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: We passed it after 9/11.

Speaker: DICKERSON
Sents: And you think that covers all of this?

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: It certainly does cover it.

Speaker: CLINTON
Sents: I would like to see it updated.

Speaker: DICKERSON
